choices.text: ε-amino groups of lysyl & N terminal valines of hemoglobin β chains
α-amino group of lysyl & N terminal valines of hemoglobin β chains
ε-amino groups of lysyl & C terminal valines of hemoglobin α chains
α-amino group of lysyl & C terminal valines of hemoglobin α chains

questions.text: A patient having type 2 diabetes mellitus since 18 years. His HbA1c level is 10%, which suggesting poor glycemic control. During formation of glycated hemoglobin, glucose enter into erythrocytes and can form a covalent adduct with:
questions.solution:
GLYCATED HEMOGLOBIN (HbA1c)

  • Blood glucose that enters the erythrocytes can form a covalent adduct with the ε-amino groups of lysyl residues and the N-terminal valines of hemoglobin β chains, a process referred to as glycation.
  • Unlike glycosylation, glycation is not enzyme catalyzed. The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood glucose concentration. Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6 to 8 weeks.
  • Measurement of HbA1c therefore provides valuable information for management of diabetes mellitus.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 6 PN 55

questions.text: Following image showing production of various globin chain during development of quaternary structure of fetal and newborn hemoglobins. Identify the type of orange colored globin chain marked with question mark.
questions.solution:
• Developmental pattern of the quaternary structure of fetal and newborn hemoglobins:

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 6 PN 51

questions.text: All of the following are diseases occurs due to abnormal protein conformation, except:
questions.solution:
• The transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, or prion diseases, are fatal neurodegenerative diseases characterized by spongiform changes, astrocytic gliomas, and neuronal loss resulting from the deposition of insoluble protein aggregates in neural cells.
  • They include Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, scrapie in sheep, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease) in cattle. A variant form of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (vCJD) that afflicts younger patients is associated with early-onset psychiatric and behavioural disorders.
  • Prion diseases may manifest themselves as infectious, genetic, or sporadic disorders. Because no viral or bacterial gene encoding the pathologic prion protein could be identified, the source and mechanism of transmission of prion disease long remained elusive. Today it is recognized that prion diseases are protein conformation diseases transmitted by altering the conformation, and hence the physical properties, of proteins endogenous to the host.
  • Human prion-related protein (PrP), a glycoprotein encoded on the short arm of chromosome 20, normally is monomeric and rich in α helix. Pathologic prion proteins serve as the templates for the conformational transformation of normal PrP, known as PrPc, into PrPsc. PrPsc is rich in β sheet with many hydrophobic aminoacyl side chains exposed to solvent.
  • As each new PrPsc molecule is formed, it triggers the production of yet more pathologic variants in a conformational chain reaction. Because PrPsc molecules associate strongly with one another through their exposed hydrophobic regions, the accumulating PrPsc units coalesce to form insoluble protease-resistant aggregates. Since one pathologic prion or prion-related protein can serve as template for the conformational transformation of many times its number of PrPc molecules, prion diseases can be transmitted by the protein alone without involvement of DNA or RNA.
  • Option B: Refolding or misfolding of another protein endogenous to human brain tissue, β-amyloid, is a prominent feature of the Alzheimer disease. While the main cause of the Alzheimer disease remains elusive, the characteristic senile plaques and neurofibrillary bundles contain aggregates of the protein β-amyloid, a 4.3-kDa polypeptide produced by proteolytic cleavage of a larger protein known as amyloid precursor protein.
  • In Alzheimer disease patients, levels of β-amyloid become elevated, and this protein undergoes a conformational transformation from a soluble α helix-rich state to a state rich in β sheet and prone to self aggregation. Apolipoprotein E has been implicated as a potential mediator of this conformational transformation.
  • Option C: Thalassemias are caused by genetic defects that impair the synthesis of one of the polypeptide subunits of hemoglobin. During the burst of hemoglobin synthesis that occurs during erythrocyte development, a specific chaperone called α-hemoglobin-stabilizing protein (AHSP) binds to free hemoglobin α-subunits awaiting incorporation into the hemoglobin multimer.
  • In the absence of this chaperone, free α-hemoglobin subunits aggregate, and the resulting precipitate has cytotoxic effects on the developing erythrocyte. Investigations using genetically modified mice suggest a role for AHSP in modulating the severity of β-thalassemia in human subjects.
  • Option D: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a group of connective tissue disorders that involve impaired integrity of supporting structures. It is genetic disease occurs due to altered codon (mutation).

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 5 PN 42

questions.text: Amino acids which absorb ultraviolet light:
questions.solution:
• The α-R groups determine the properties of amino acids. The presence of aromatic ring in R groups confirms property of absorbing ultraviolet light.

So Option C is correct answer.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 3 PN 20

choices.text: May have Positive, Negative or Zero Net Charge
At its Isoelectric pH, they bear no net charge

questions.text: All statement regarding naturally occurring amino acids are correct, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Amino Acids May Have Positive, Negative, or Zero Net Charge depending on pH of medium.
  • Option B: All amino acids in protein share the absolute configuration of L-glyceraldehyde and thus are defined as L-αamino acids.
  • Option C: Amino acids in some protein may be modified by post translational modification.

Posttranslational modifications can generate novel R groups that impart further properties. In collagen, protein-bound proline and lysine residues are converted to 4-hydroxyproline and 5-hydroxylysine.

  • Option D: At Its Isoelectric pH (pI), an amino acid bears no net charge.

Zwitterions are one example of an isoelectric species-the form of a molecule that has an equal number of positive and negative charges and thus is electrically neutral. The isoelectric pH, also called the pI, is the pH midway between pKa values for the ionizations on either side of the isoelectric species.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 3 PN 19

questions.text: Following image showing protein which exist in:
questions.solution:
FOUR ORDERS OF PROTEIN STRUCTURE

  • Option A: Primary structure denotes the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain;
  • Option B: Secondary structure denotes the folding of short (3-30 residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units;
  • Option C: Tertiary structure denotes the assembly of secondary structural units into larger functional units such as the mature polypeptide and its component domains.
  • Option D: Quaternary structure denotes the number and types of polypeptide units of oligomeric proteins and their spatial arrangement.
  • Above image showing four different globin polypeptide chains with heme prosthetic group (structure of hemoglobin), so it will be exist in quaternary form.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 5 PN 34

questions.text: All of the following reagents are used for identifying the first amino acid in proteins, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Pehr Edman introduced phenyl isothiocyanate (Edman reagent) to selectively label the amino-terminal residue of a peptide. In contrast to Sanger reagent, the phenylthiohydantoin (PTH) derivative can be removed under mild conditions to generate a new amino-terminal residue.
  • Successive rounds of derivatization with Edman reagent can therefore be used to sequence many residues of a single sample of peptide. Even with the benefit of Edman reagent, the determination of the complete sequence of a protein by chemical methods remains a time- and labor-intensive process.
  • Option B: Frederick Sanger reduced the disulfide bonds, separated the A and B chains, and cleaved each chain into smaller peptides using trypsin, chymotrypsin, and pepsin. The resulting peptides were then isolated and hydrolyzed into a mixture of smaller peptides by treatment with acid.
  • Each peptide in the mixture was isolated and treated with 1-fluoro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (Sanger reagent), which reacts with the exposed α-amino groups of the amino-terminal residues. The amino acid content of each peptide was then determined and the amino terminal amino acid was identified.
  • The ε-amino group of lysine also reacts with Sanger reagent; but since an aminoterminal lysine reacts with 2 mol of Sanger reagent, it is readily distinguished from a lysine from the interior of a peptide. Working from di- and tripeptides up through progressively larger fragments, Sanger was able to reconstruct the complete sequence of insulin, an accomplishment for which he received a Nobel Prize in 1958.
  • Option C: Cynogen bromide is used to immobilize proteins by coupling them to agarose for affinity chromatography
  • Option D: Dansyl chloride is a reagent that reacts with primary amino group of amino acids and identify them.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 4 PN 27

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to ophthalmologist with progressive myopia and premature cataract. Based on history and further examination, he found to have progressive gyrate atrophy of choroid and retina. He had elevate plasma and urinary ornithine. Further genetic analysis shows mutation in gene encoding enzyme ornithine transaminase. Which of following amino acid should be restricted in diet of this patient to prevent further progression?
questions.solution:
• The initial reactions in arginine catabolism are conversion to ornithine followed by transamination of ornithine to glutamate-γ-semialdehyde. Subsequent catabolism of glutamate-γ-semialdehyde to α-ketoglutarate and glutamate occurs.
  • Mutations in ornithine δ-aminotransferase (ornithine transaminase) elevate plasma and urinary ornithine, and are associated with gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina. Treatment involves restricting dietary arginine.

  • Option C: As arginine is converted into ornithine and leading to gyrate atrophy of choroids and retina. So dietary restriction of arginine will prevent it.
  • Option A: Phenylalanine is restricted in patient of phenylketonuria.

So Option C is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 283

questions.text: Which of the following is purely ketogenic amino acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Leucine and lysine are purely ketogenic amino acids.
  • Option B & Option D: Isoleucine, phenyl alanine, tyrosine and tryptophane are both ketogenic and glucogenic amino acids.
  • Option C: Rest are purely glucogenic amino acids.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 281

questions.text: A 3 year old male child has delayed developmental mile stone. He has friable, tufted hair. An elevated levels of argininosuccinate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine. Most likely metabolic defect is in enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Option A: In addition to patients who lack detectable argininosuccinate synthetase activity, a 25-fold elevated Km for citrulline has been reported. In the resulting citrullinemia, plasma and cerebrospinal fluid citrulline levels are elevated, and 1 to 2 g of citrulline are excreted daily.
  • Option B: Argininosuccinic aciduria, accompanied by elevated levels of argininosuccinate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, is associated with friable, tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa). Both early- and late-onset types are known. The metabolic defect is in argininosuccinate lyase. Diagnosis by the measurement of erythrocyte argininosuccinate lyase activity can be performed on umbilical cord blood or amniotic fluid cells.
  • Option C: The hyperornithinaemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome results from mutation of the ORNT1 gene that encodes the mitochondrial membrane ornithine permease. The failure to import cytosolic ornithine into the mitochondrial matrix renders the urea cycle inoperable, with consequent hyperammonemia, and hyperornithinaemia due to the accompanying accumulation of cytosolic ornithine. In the absence of its normal acceptor (ornithine), mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate carbamoylates lysine to homocitrulline, resulting in homocitrullinuria.
  • Option D: The X-chromosome-linked deficiency termed 'hyperammonemia type 2' reflects a defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase. The mothers also exhibit hyperammonemia and an aversion to high-protein foods. Levels of glutamine are elevated in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, probably as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 278

choices.text: Specific for alpha amino group of amino acid only
All 20 standard amino acids under goes transamination reactions

questions.text: Transamination reaction is:
questions.solution:
• Transamination transfers α-amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate and forming glutamate by enzyme transaminase.
  • Transamination reactions interconvert pairs of α-amino acids and α-keto acids.
  • Option A: Transamination is not restricted to α-amino groups. The δ-amino group of ornithine (but not the ε-amino group of lysine) readily undergoes transamination.
  • Option B: All of the common amino acids except lysine, threonine, proline, and hydroxyproline participate in transamination.
  • Option C: Transamination reactions are freely reversible,
  • Option D: They also function in amino acid biosynthesis.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 273

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid undergoes oxidative deamination?
questions.solution:
• Each aminotransferase is specific for one pair of substrates, but nonspecific for the other pair. The α-amino nitrogen from all amino acids that undergo transamination can be concentrated in glutamate. This is important because l-glutamate is the only amino acid that undergoes oxidative deamination at an appreciable rate in mammalian tissues.
  • The formation of ammonia from α-amino groups thus occurs mainly via the α-amino nitrogen of l-glutamate.

So Option A is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 273

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics clinical features of urea cycle disorders, except:
questions.solution:
• Urea cycle disorders are characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis, not respiratory acidosis.
  • Option A: Urea cycle converts NH3 into urea. So any urea cycle disorders will increase ammonia level and lead to hyperammonemia.
  • Option B: Increase ammonia level damages brain and lead to encephalopathy.
  • Option C & Option D: Increase ammonia level will lead to respiratory alkalosis, not respiratory acidosis.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 277

questions.text: All of the following are excreted in urine in cystinuria, except:
questions.solution:
• Cystinuria is a defect in renal reabsorption of amino acids, where Cystine, lysine, arginine, and ornithine are excreted. So also termed as cystine-lysinuria.

But citrulline is not excreted. So Option A is correct.

  • Apart from cystine calculi, cystinuria is benign. The mixed disulfide of l-cysteine and l-homocysteine excreted by cystinuric patients is more soluble than cystine and reduces formation of cystine calculi.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 283

questions.text: Which of the following metalloprotein contain Manganese?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Aconitase contain Fe - S center.
  • Option B: Dopamine beta hydroxylase contain Copper.
  • Option C: Matrix metalloprotease contain zinc.
  • Option D: Galactosyl transferase contain Mn, it is involved in glycoprotein synthesis

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 10 PN 97

questions.text: Inhibition of Δ-aminolevulinate synthase by lead poisoning is due to:
questions.solution:
• Toxicity of heavy metals
  • Most heavy metals, a loosely defined term for metallic elements with densities greater than 5 g/cm3 or atomic numbers > 20, are toxic. Some well-known examples include arsenic, antimony, lead, mercury, and cadmium, whose toxicity can arise via a number of mechanisms like Displacement of an Essential Cation, Enzyme Inactivation and Formation of Reactive Oxygen Species.
  • Option A: Displacement of an Essential Cation:

The ability of a heavy metal to displace a functionally essential metal can readily lead to loss or impairment of function. Classic examples include the displacement of iron by gallium in the enzymes ribonucleotide reductase and Fe, Cu superoxide dismutase. Ga3+, while of similar size and identical charge to Fe3+, lacks the multivalence capability of iron. Replacement of Fe3+ by Ga3+ therefore renders affected enzymes catalytically inert.

  • Option B: Heavy metals are not displacing anions.
  • Option C: Enzyme Inactivation: Heavy metals readily form adducts with free sulfhydryl groups. If present in proteins, formation of these adducts undermines a protein's structural integrity, with concomitant impairment of function. Examples include the inhibition of δ-aminolevulinate synthase by Pb and the inactivation of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex by arsenic or mercury. In pyruvate dehydrogenase, the heavy metals react with the sulfhydryl on the essential prosthetic group, lipoic acid, rather than with a peptidyl cysteine.
  • Option D: Formation of Reactive Oxygen Species: Heavy metals can induce the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can then damage DNA, membrane lipids, and other biomolecules. Oxidative damage to DNA can cause genetic mutations that may lead to cancer or other pathophysiologic conditions. ROS-mediated peroxidation of lipid molecules can lead to the loss of membrane integrity.
  • The resulting dissipation of action potentials and disruption of various cross-membrane transport processes can be particularly deleterious to neurologic and neuromuscular functions. It has also been reported that rats fed with excessive levels of heavy metals are prone to develop cancerous tumors.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 10 PN 94

questions.text: The enzymes ribonucleotide reductase renders catalytically inert by gallium by which one of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Toxicity of heavy metals
  • Most heavy metals, a loosely defined term for metallic elements with densities greater than 5 g/cm3 or atomic numbers > 20, are toxic. Some well-known examples include arsenic, antimony, lead, mercury, and cadmium, whose toxicity can arise via a number of mechanisms like Displacement of an Essential Cation, Enzyme Inactivation and Formation of Reactive Oxygen Species.
  • Option A: Displacement of an Essential Cation:

The ability of a heavy metal to displace a functionally essential metal can readily lead to loss or impairment of function. Classic examples include the displacement of iron by gallium in the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase and Fe, Cu superoxide dismutase. Ga3+, while of similar size and identical charge to Fe3+, lacks the multivalence capability of iron. Replacement of Fe3+ by Ga3+ therefore renders affected enzymes catalytically inert.

  • Option B: Heavy metals are not displacing anions.
  • Option C: Enzyme Inactivation: Heavy metals readily form adducts with free sulfhydryl groups. If present in proteins, formation of these adducts undermines a protein's structural integrity, with concomitant impairment of function. Examples include the inhibition of δ-aminolevulinate synthase by Pb and the inactivation of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex by arsenic or mercury. In pyruvate dehydrogenase, the heavy metals react with the sulfhydryl on the essential prosthetic group, lipoic acid, rather than with a peptidyl cysteine.
  • Option D: Formation of Reactive Oxygen Species: Heavy metals can induce the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can then damage DNA, membrane lipids, and other biomolecules. Oxidative damage to DNA can cause genetic mutations that may lead to cancer or other pathophysiologic conditions. ROS-mediated peroxidation of lipid molecules can lead to the loss of membrane integrity. The resulting dissipation of action potentials and disruption of various cross-membrane transport processes can be particularly deleterious to neurologic and neuromuscular functions. It has also been reported that rats fed with excessive levels of heavy metals are prone to develop cancerous tumors.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 10 PN 93

choices.text: Used to form the ketone bodies

questions.text: All of the following are fates of Acetyl-CoA formed by β-oxidation of fatty acids, except:
questions.solution:
• Acetyl-CoA formed by β-oxidation of fatty acids may undergo three fates:
  1. As with acetyl-CoA arising from glycolysis, it is oxidized to CO2 + H2O via the citric acid cycle. (Option A)
  2. It is the precursor for synthesis of cholesterol and other steroids. (Option C)
  3. In the liver, it is used to form the ketone bodies, acetoacetate, and 3-hydroxybutyrate, which are important fuels in prolonged fasting and starvation. (Option D)

  • Option B: Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors such as lactate, amino acids, and glycerol. (not from acetyl CoA).

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 131

questions.text: Synthesis of dispensable amino acids occurs mainly by:
questions.solution:
• The amino acids are required for protein synthesis. Some must be supplied in the diet (the essential or indispensable amino acids), since they cannot be synthesized in the body. The remainder are nonessential or dispensable amino acids, which are supplied in the diet, but can also be formed in body.
  • Option A: The nonessential or dispensable amino acids formed from metabolic intermediates by transamination using the amino group from other amino acids.
  • Option B: Deamination is removal of amino group from amino acid. It occurs in liver during catabolism of amino acids.
  • After deamination, amino nitrogen is excreted as urea, and the carbon skeletons that remain after transamination may (1) be oxidized to CO2 via the citric acid cycle, (2) be used to synthesize glucose (gluconeogenesis), or (3) form ketone bodies or acetyl-CoA, which may be oxidized or used for synthesis of fatty acids.
  • Option C: Carboxylation is process of addition of CO2 group in amino acids, it is important in synthesis of some neurotransmitters.
  • Option D: Translation is synthesis of protein from amino acids, occurs in ribosome with help of mRNA, tRNA & rRNA.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 131

questions.text: The process of breakdown of fatty acid into acetyl CoA is termed as:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Lipolysis is breakdown of TG into fatty acid.
  • Option B: Lipogenesis is the process of synthesis of fatty acid from acetyl CoA.
  • Option C: Esterification is synthesis of TG from fatty acid.
  • Option D: Beta oxidation is the process of breakdown of fatty acid into acetyl CoA.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 131

questions.text: The level of all of the following hormone or metabolic fuel in blood is increased during the onset of starvation, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: The level of insulin is decreased during onset of starvation. The level of insulin is increased in fed state.
  • Option B, Option C, Option D: The level of glucagon, fatty acid & ketone body are increased during onset of starvation.
  • Relative changes in plasma hormones and metabolic fuels during the onset of starvation

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 139

questions.text: Glucose and galactose are:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Isomers differing as a result of variations in configuration of the -OH and -H on carbon atoms 2, 3, and 4 of glucose are known as epimers. Biologically, the most important epimers of glucose are mannose (epimerized at carbon 2) and galactose (epimerized at carbon 4).

  • Option D: Galactose and mannose are not epimers but termed as diastereoisomers.
  • Option B: Alpha- and beta-anomers: The ring structure of an aldose is a hemiacetal, since it is formed by reaction between an aldehyde and an alcohol group. Similarly, the ring structure of a ketose is a hemiketal. Crystalline glucose is α-d-glucopyranose. The cyclic structure is retained in the solution, but isomerism occurs about position 1, the carbonyl or anomeric carbon atom, to give a mixture of α-glucopyranose (38%) and β-glucopyranose (62%). Less than 0.3% is represented by α- and β-anomers of glucofuranose.
  • Option C: Aldose-ketose isomerism: Fructose has the same molecular formula as glucose but differs in that there is a potential keto group in position 2, the anomeric carbon of fructose, whereas in glucose there is a potential aldehyde group in position 1, the anomeric carbon.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 143

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitors of glucose metabolism experimentally?
questions.solution:
• Deoxy Sugars Lack an Oxygen Atom Deoxy sugars are those in which one hydroxyl group has been replaced by hydrogen. An example is deoxyribose in DNA. The deoxy sugar l-fucose occurs in glycoproteins; 2-deoxyglucose is used experimentally as an inhibitor of glucose metabolism.

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 145

questions.text: Which of the following molecule is also known as animal starch?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dextrin:

  • produced by the partial hydrolysis of starch along with maltose and glucose
  • dextrins are often referred to as either amylodextrins, erythrodextrins or achrodextrins
  • used as mucilages (glues)

Option B: Dextran

  • products of the reaction of glucose and the enzyme transglucosidase from Leuconostoc mesenteroides
  • used as plasma extenders (treatment of shock)
  • also used as molecular sieves to separate proteins and other large molecules (gel filtration chromatography)
  • components of dental plaques

Option C: Glycogen:

  • Glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals and is sometimes called animal starch.
  • It is a more highly branched structure than amylopectin, with chains of 12 to 15 α-d-glucopyranose residues (in α1 → 4 glucosidic linkage) with branching by means of α1 → 6 glucosidic bonds.
  • Muscle glycogen granules (β-particles) are spherical and contain up to 60,000 glucose residues; in liver there are similar granules and also rosettes of glycogen granules that appear to be aggregated β-particles.

Option D: Chitin

  • chitin is present in the cell wall of fungi and in the exoskeletons of anthropods likecrustaceans, insects and spiders
  • chitin is Linear, unbranched homopolymer of N-acetylglucosamine units in (b1®4) linkage.
  • used commercially in coatings (extends the shelf life of fruits and meats)

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 145

questions.text: A patient of liver failure presented with hepatic encephalopathy. Serum ammonia level is 345 micromol/L (Normal 10 to 30 micromol/L). Which of the following enzyme of TCA cycle is inhibited by such high concentration of ammonia?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Malonic acid inhibits succinate dehydrogenase enzyme.
  • Option B: High concentrations of ammonia inhibit α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Arsenic also inhibit enzyme alpha keto glutarate dehydrogenase.
  • Option C: Aconitase is inhibited by Fluoroacetate.
  • Option D: Cytochrome oxidase is complex IV in ECT and it is inhibited by Cyanide, Azide, Carbon monoxide (CO), H2

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 16 PN 153

questions.text: Total number of ATPs are formed during one turn of TCA cycle are:
questions.solution:
• Ten ATP are formed per turn of the citric acid cycle, How?
  • As a result of oxidations catalyzed by the dehydrogenases of the citric acid cycle, three molecules of NADH and one of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA catabolized in one turn of the cycle.
  • These reducing equivalents are transferred to the respiratory chain, where reoxidation of each NADH results in formation of ~2.5 ATP, and of FADH2 , ~1.5 ATP. In addition, 1 ATP (or GTP) is formed by substrate-level phosphorylation catalyzed by succinate thiokinase.

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 16 PN 153

choices.text: Riboflavin is cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase
Riboflavin is an electron acceptor for isocitrate dehydrogenase
Niacin is electron acceptor for α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Thiamine is the coenzyme for α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Vitamins play key roles in the citric acid cycle. All of the following sentences are representing appropriate role of specific vitamin in TCA cycle, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Riboflavin, as FAD, is the cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase.
  • Option B & Option C: Niacin, as NAD+, is the electron acceptor for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase.
  • Option D: Thiamine, as thiamine diphosphate, is the coenzyme for decarboxylation in the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reaction.
  • Four of the B vitamins are essential in the citric acid cycle and hence energy-yielding metabolism:

1) riboflavin, as FAD, is the cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase;

2) niacin, as NAD+, is the electron acceptor for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase;

3) thiamine, as thiamine diphosphate, is the coenzyme for decarboxylation in the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reaction; and

4) pantothenic acid, as part of coenzyme A, is esterified to carboxylic acids to form acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 16 PN 153

questions.text: The production of lactate occurs in all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glycolysis in erythrocytes always terminates in lactate, because the subsequent reactions of pyruvate oxidation are mitochondrial, and erythrocytes lack mitochondria.
  • Option B & Option D: Lactate production is high in vigorous exercise, septic shock and cancer cachexia. Skeletal muscle, particularly the white fibers, where the rate of work output, and hence the need for ATP formation, may exceed the rate at which oxygen can be taken up and utilized.
  • Option C: Vitamin B1 is required as cofactor for enzyme Pyruvate dehydrogenase which converts pyruvate into acetyl CoA. As result of vitamin B1 deficiency, activity of this enzyme is reduced, which lead to accumulation of pyruvate which convert into lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Niacin deficiency lead to pellagra, where lactic acidosis not seen.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 17 PN 160

questions.text: Name the coenzyme used for following reaction as indicated (by ?) in below image:
questions.solution:
• Propionate is a major precursor of glucose in ruminants; it enters gluconeogenesis via the citric acid cycle.
  • After esterification with CoA, propionyl-CoA is carboxylated to d-methylmalonyl-CoA, catalysed by propionyl-CoA carboxylase, a biotin-dependent enzyme.
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA racemase catalyzes the conversion of d-methylmalonyl-CoA to l-methylmalonyl-CoA, which then undergoes isomerization to succinyl-CoA catalyzed by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase.
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme, and in deficiency, methylmalonic acid is excreted in the urine (methylmalonic aciduria).

So Option D is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 19 PN 174

questions.text: The enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Enzymes Lower the Activation Energy Barrier for a Reaction
  • All enzymes accelerate reaction rates by lowering ΔGF for the formation of transition states. However, they may differ in the way this is achieved. While the sequence of chemical steps at the active site parallels those which occur when the substrates react in the absence of a catalyst, the environment of the active site lowers ΔGF by stabilizing the transition state intermediates.
  • To put it another way, the enzyme can be envisioned as binding to the transition state intermediate more tightly than it does to either substrates or products. A stabilization can involve
  • (1) acid-base groups suitably positioned to transfer protons to or from the developing transition state intermediate,
  • (2) suitably positioned charged groups or metal ions that stabilize developing charges, or
  • (3) the imposition of steric strain on substrates so that their geometry approaches that of the transition state.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 8 PN 72

questions.text: Enzymes that involved in reactions includes hydrolytic cleavage of C-C bonds are termed as:
questions.solution:
• International Union of Biochemistry (IUB) developed a system of enzyme nomenclature in which each enzyme has a unique name and code number that identify the type of reaction catalyzed. Enzymes are grouped into six classes.
  • Option A: Hydrolases-enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.
  • Option B: Lyases-enzymes that catalyze cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.
  • Option C: Isomerases-enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
  • Option D: Oxidoreductases-enzymes that catalyze oxidations and reductions.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 7 PN 57

questions.text: All of the following Coenzymes are involved in donating or accepting hydrogen atoms during reaction, excepts:
questions.solution:
• Co-enzymes may be divided into two groups:
  1. Those taking part in reactions catalysed by Oxido- reductases by donating or accepting hydrogen atoms or electrons. Examples are…NAD+, NADP+, FMN, FAD, Coenzyme Q
  2. Those taking part in reactions transferring group other than hydrogen:

Examples are…Thiamine pyrophosphate, Pantothenic acid (CoA SH), pyridoxal phosphate, Folate coenzyme, Biotin, Cobamide coenzyme

  • Option A, Option B, Option C: NADP, Coenzyme Q & FMN are involved in donating or accepting hydrogen atoms during reaction.
  • Option D: Pantothenic acid is not involved in transfer of hydrogen atoms during reaction.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 7 PN 58

questions.text: Graph given in following image is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Hyperbolic curve showing Effect of substrate concentration on the initial velocity of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction

  • Option B: A plot of 1/vi as y as a function of 1/[S] as x therefore gives a straight line whose y intercept is 1/Vmax and whose slope is Km/Vmax. Such a plot is called a double reciprocal or Lineweaver-Burk plot.

  • Option C: A graphical representation of a linear form of the Hill equation is used to evaluate S50, the substrate concentration that produces half-maximal velocity, and the degree of cooperativity n.

  • Option D: Graph showing effect of pH on enzyme activity is bell shape as shown in below image.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 8 PN 75

choices.text: the factor by which the rate of a biologic process increases for a 20°C increase in temperature
the factor by which the rate of a biologic process decreases for a 10°C increase in temperature
the factor by which the rate of a biologic process increases for a 10°C increase in temperature
the factor by which the rate of a biologic process decreases for a 20°C increase in temperature

questions.text: The temperature coefficient (Q10) is
questions.solution:
• The temperature coefficient (Q10) is the factor by which the rate of a biologic process increases for a 10°C increase in temperature. For the temperatures over which enzymes are stable, the rates of most biologic processes typically double for a 10°C rise in temperature (Q10 = 2).
  • Changes in the rates of enzyme catalyzed reactions that accompany a rise or fall in body temperature constitute a prominent survival feature for 'cold-blooded' life forms such as lizards or fish, whose body temperatures are dictated by the external environment.
  • However, for mammals and other homeothermic organisms, changes in enzyme reaction rates with temperature assume physiologic importance only in circumstances such as fever or hypothermia.

So Option C is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 8 PN 72

questions.text: Which of the following is an omega 9 fatty acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Elaidic acid (C18:1;9) is Omega 9 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option B & Option D: Linoleic acid (C18:2;9,12) & Gamma linolenic acid (C18:3;6,9,12) is Omega 6 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option C: Alpha linolenic acid (C18:3;6,9,12) is Omega 3 unsaturated fatty acid.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 197

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipid does not contain glycerol?
questions.solution:
• Option A: phosphatidyl choline (lecithin) is made up of Glycerol + FA + Phosphate + Choline.
  • Option B: Sphingomyelins contain no glycerol. It is made up of fatty acid, phosphoric acid, choline, and sphingosine.

  • Option C: phosphatidyl Ethanol amine (Cephalin) is made up of Glycerol + FA + Phosphate + Ethanol amine.
  • Option D: phosphatidyl Inositol is made up of Glycerol + FA + Phosphate + Inositol.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 200

questions.text: Most abundant phospholipid in mitochondrial membrane is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glycerophospholipids containing choline, (phosphatidylcholines, commonly called lecithins) are the most abundant phospholipids of the cell membrane and represent a large proportion of the body's store of choline.
  • Option B: Cardiolipin Is a Major Lipid of Mitochondrial Membranes
  • Phosphatidic acid is a precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, which in turn gives rise to cardiolipin. This phospholipid is found only in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function.
  • Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathologic conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism, and Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).
  • Option C: Phosphatidylethanolamine (cephalin) and phosphatidylserine (found in most tissues) are also found in cell membranes.
  • Option D: Phosphatidylinositol is a precursor of second messengers.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 201

questions.text: The only step in the complete degradation of a fatty acid that requires energy is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: In final step of beta oxidation, 3-ketoacyl-CoA is split at the 2,3-position by thiolase (3-ketoacyl-CoA-thiolase), forming acetyl-CoA and a new acyl-CoA two carbons shorter than the original acyl-CoA molecule. It doesn't require energy.
  • Option B: Fatty acids must first be converted to an active intermediate before they can be catabolized. This is the only step in the complete degradation of a fatty acid that requires energy from ATP.
  • In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase (thiokinase) catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid (or FFA) to an 'active fatty acid' or acyl-CoA, using one high energy phosphate and forming AMP and PPi.
  • Option C: The first step during beta oxidation is the removal of two hydrogen atoms from the 2(α)- and 3(β)-carbon atoms, catalyzed by acyl-CoA dehydrogenase and requiring flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). This results in the formation of Δ2 -trans-enoyl-CoA and FADH2.
  • Option D: In second step during beta oxidation, water is added to saturate the double bond and form 3-hydroxyacyl CoA, catalyzed by Δ2 -enoyl-CoA hydratase.
  • In third step of beta oxidation, 3-hydroxy derivative undergoes further dehydrogenation on the 3-carbon catalyzed by l-3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase to form the corresponding 3-ketoacyl-CoA compound. In this case, NAD+ is the coenzyme involved.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 208

choices.text: Very long chain fatty acid (C20, C22)

questions.text: Which of the following type of fatty acids are oxidized by peroxisomal β-oxidation?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Long chain fatty acid (C16, C18) are oxidised by mitochondrial beta oxidation.
  • Option B: A modified form of β-oxidation is found in peroxisomes and leads to the breakdown of very-long-chain fatty acids (eg, C20, C22) with the formation of acetyl-CoA and H2O2, which is broken down by catalase.
  • Option C & Option D: The CoA esters of unsaturated fatty acids are degraded by the enzymes normally responsible for β-oxidation until either a Δ3 -cis-acyl-CoA compound or a Δ4 -cis-acyl-CoA compound is formed, depending on the position of the double bonds.
  • The former compound is isomerized (Δ3 cis → Δ2 -trans-enoyl-CoA isomerase) to the corresponding Δ2 -trans-CoA stage of β-oxidation for subsequent hydration and oxidation. Any Δ4 -cis-acyl-CoA either remaining, as in the case of linoleic acid, or entering the pathway at this point after conversion by acyl-CoA dehydrogenase to Δ2 -trans-Δ4 -cis-dienoyl-CoA, is then metabolized.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 210

questions.text: A 76 year old male presented with unconsciousness in emergency. On history it was found that he had fasting since last 20 days. His blood sugar level is below normal (around 64 mg/dl) and ketone bodies found in blood. Glucose is not detected in urine, but ketone bodies found in urine. Which of the following ketone body is quantitatively predominantly present in blood and urine?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Acetone is excreted via lung, and give acetone smell in breadth.
  • Option B: Acetoacetate is a ketone body found in blood, but quantitatively less than beta hydroxy butyrate.
  • Option C: Beta hydroxy butyrate (d-3-Hydroxybutyrate) is quantitatively the predominant ketone body present in the blood and urine in ketosis.
  • Option D: Acetyl CoA is a is not a ketone body.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 196

questions.text: Which of the following is excreted unchanged in urine during degradation of transfer RNA?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Dihydrouracil is breakdown beta alanine, CO2 & NH3 & then excreted.
  • Option B: Pseudouridine is present in transfer RNA. No human enzyme catalyzes hydrolysis or phosphorolysis of the pseudouridine (ψ). This unusual nucleotide therefore is excreted unchanged in the urine of normal subjects during degradation of transfer RNA.
  • Option C: Purine ribonucleotide when breakdown it produces urea as an end product. Urea excreted by kidney.
  • Option D: The end product of pyrimidine catabolism will be beta amino isobutyrate or beta alanine, CO2 & NH3 & then excreted.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 32 PN 325

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme initiate urea biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Arginase breakdown arginine into urea and ornithine in last step.
  • Option B: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I initiate urea biosynthesis.
  • Condensation of CO2 , ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate is catalyzed by mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I.
  • Option C: A cytosolic form of this enzyme, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II, uses glutamine rather than ammonia as the nitrogen donor and functions in pyrimidine biosynthesis.
  • Option D: l-Ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes transfer of the carbamoyl group of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine, forming citrulline and orthophosphate.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 275

questions.text:
The three processes that contribute to purine nucleotide biosynthesis are:
1) phosphorylation of purine nucleoside
2) synthesis from amphiblic intermediate and
3) phosphoribosylation of purines
The correct arrangement in order of decreasing importance are:
questions.solution:
• The three processes that contribute to purine nucleotide biosynthesis are, in order of decreasing importance:

1) Synthesis from amphibolic intermediates (synthesis de novo)

2) Phosphoribosylation of purines

3) Phosphorylation of purine nucleosides

So Option A is correct option.

  • All dietary nucleic acids and nucleotides are nonessential, they will not be incorporated into tissue nucleic acids. Following ingestion of nucleotide or nucleic acid in diet, their degradation result in mononucleotides, which may be absorbed or converted to purine and pyrimidine bases.
  • The purine bases are then oxidized to uric acid, which may be absorbed and excreted in the urine. Pyrimidine bases are degraded into CO2, NH3, beta alanine and beta aminoisobutyrate.
  • De novo synthesis is major pathway which provides nucleotides to tissue to meet their physiological demands. During de novo synthesis in tissue, purine or pyrimidine nucleotide are produced from various amphibolic intermediates.
  • During phosphorylation of purines, there is an addition of ribose phosphate to preformed purine or pyrimidine bases.
  • During phosphorylation of purine nucleosides, there is an addition of phosphate to nucleoside.
  • Both phosphorylation of purines and Phosphorylation of purine nucleosides occurs during salvage pathway. Such purine or pyrimidine bases or purine nucleosides are derived from damaged DNA of broken down cells (recycled).

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 33 PN 328

questions.text: All of the following are source of carbon atoms of purine ring during purine biosynthesis, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option B & Option D: CO2, Glycine and Tetrahydrofolate are source of carbon for purine ring during purine biosynthesis.
  • Option C: Serine is not source of carbon for purine ring during purine biosynthesis.

Sources of the nitrogen and carbon atoms of the purine ring.


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 33 PN 328

questions.text: Which of the following prevent reannealing of ssDNA during DNA replication?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Single stranded binding protein (SSB) prevent reannealing of ssDNA to form dsDNA during DNA replication.
  • Option B: Topoisomerase relieves torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding
  • Option C: Helicase lead to ATP driven processive unwinding of DNA
  • Option D: DNA Primase initiates synthesis of RNA primers

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 35 PN 362

questions.text: Which of the following DNA repair mechanism is found to be defective in Xeroderma pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
• Repair of damaged DNA is critical for maintaining genomic integrity and thereby preventing the propagation of mutations, either horizontally (somatic cells), or vertically (germ cells).
  • DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical, and biologic assaults on a daily basis, hence efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions is essential. Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways.
  • The mechanisms of DNA repair include
  • Nucleotide excision repair (NER);
  • Mismatch repair (MMR);
  • Base excision repair (BER);
  • Homologous recombination (HR); and n
  • Nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) repair pathways

There are many diseases are associated with defective DNA repair mechanism:


So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 35 PN 370

questions.text: Free radical damage to DNA can convert guanine into 8 oxoguanine. Such 8 oxoguanine lesion induced in DNA can repaired by:
questions.solution:
• DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical, and biologic assaults on a daily basis, hence efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions is essential. Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways.

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 35 PN 370

questions.text: Porphyrias are group of metabolic disorders characterized by accumulation & excretion of porphyrins or porphyrin precursors in body.Activity of one of enzymes involved in heme synthesis is decreased,so intermediates accumulated.It is characterized by neurological symptoms and photosensitivity in general. Which one of the following is an appropriate treatment modality in patients of porphyrias ?
questions.solution:
• Possible Treatments for Porphyrias

Present treatment of porphyrias is essentially symptomatic:

  • Option A: Certain drugs (eg, barbiturates, griseofulvin) induce the production of cytochrome P450. In patients with porphyria, this can precipitate an attack of porphyria by depleting heme levels.
  • The compensating derepression of synthesis of ALAS1 then results in increased levels of potentially harmful heme precursors.

So avoiding drugs that induce production of cytochrome P450,

  • Option B: Patients exhibiting photosensitivity benefit from sunscreens and possibly from administered β-carotene, which appears to lessen production of free radicals, decreasing photosensitivity.
  • Option C: Ingestion of large amounts of carbohydrate is advisable as glucose prevent induction of ALA Synthase, so decreased production of heme precursors.
  • Option D: Hematin should be given as administration of hematin to repress ALAS1 synthesis to diminish production of harmful heme precursors.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 31 PN 311

questions.text: A 23 year old female patient was diagnosed as malaria by general practitioner and started treatment for malaria. A day later, she noticed that she was passing dark yellow urine & brown color stool. Which of the following alteration in LFT is seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
• This patient has hemolytic jaundice secondary to malaria. In hemolytic jaundice,
  • Option A: Bilirubin is absent in urine.
  • Option B: Urinary urobilinogen is increased which lead to dark yellow color or urine.
  • Option C: Stool stercobilinogen is increased which lead to dark color of stool.
  • Option D: Indirect bilirubin (unconjugated bilirubin) is increased in serum.

Hemolytic Jaundice (Prehepatic Jaundice)

  • Pathogenesis: Overproduction of Bilirubin (increased rate of hemolysis or Ineffective erythropoiesis) which exceeds the liver's ability to conjugate it

Causes are:

  1. Increased Hemolysis (Intravascular or Extravascular): Inherited disorder like Congenital spherocytosis, G6PD deficiency, malaria etc, Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (Pernicious anemia), Paroxysmal Nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), Toxins like carbon tetrachloride
  2. Ineffective erythropoiesis due to structurally abnormal Hb: Thalassemias, Sickle cell anemia
  • Symptoms: weakness, Dark urine, anemia, Icterus, splenomegaly
  • Lab findings:

Unconjugated bilirubin in blood

No bilirubin in urine

Urine Urobilinogens, so Dark color

Stool stercobilin, so Dark color



Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 31 PN 315

choices.text: Same codon for lower and higher eukaryotes
Does not involve any overlap of codon during reading frame
Some amino acids are encoded by several codons
Single codon never decodes for two amino acids

questions.text: Unambiguous nature of genetic code indicates:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Genetic code is usually same from lower and higher eukaryotes, including humans, except those of mitochondrial codes. This is an universal nature of genetic code.
  • Option B: The reading of the genetic code during the process of protein synthesis does not involve any overlap of codons. Thus, the genetic code is
  • Option C: Degeneracy in the genetic code is multiple codons decode the same amino acid.
  • Some amino acids are encoded by several codons; for example, six different codons, UCU, UCC, UCA, UCG, AGU, and AGC all specify serine. Other amino acids, such as methionine and tryptophan, have a single codon.
  • Option D: For any specific codon, only a single amino acid is specified. Single codon never decodes for two amino acids during protein synthesis. This is termed as Unambiguous nature of genetic code.

Genetic code

  • Genetic information, stored in the chromosomes and transmitted to daughter cells
  • through DNA replication. But it is expressed through transcription to mRNA (messenger RNA), subsequent translation into proteins (polypeptide chains) with help of tRNA (transfer RNA). During translation the language of the nucleotide sequence on the mRNA is translated into the language of an amino acid sequence.
  • Translation requires a genetic code, through which the information contained in the nucleic acid sequence is expressed to produce a specific sequence of amino acids. Any alteration in the nucleic acid sequence may result in an incorrect amino acid being inserted into the polypeptide chain, potentially causing disease or even death of the organism.
  • Genetic code determines which amino acids are coded for by an mRNA. Codons are presented in mRNA language of four nucleotides (adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C) and uracil (U)). The four nucleotide bases are used to produce the three-base codons. So 64 different combinations of bases, taken three at a time (a triplet code).

  • The genetic code is virtually universal. An exception occurs in mitochondria, in which a few codons have meanings different than those shown in table.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 37 PN 394
